paragraph.content: Must not exceed the following percentages of the amount of the outstanding loan balance prepaid:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-2-ii-A
paragraph.content: 2 percent, if incurred during the first two years following consummation; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-2-ii-B
paragraph.content: 1 percent, if incurred during the third year following consummation.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-3
paragraph.title: Alternative offer required.
paragraph.content: Alternative offer required. A creditor must not offer a consumer a covered transaction with a prepayment penalty unless the creditor also offers the consumer an alternative covered transaction without a prepayment penalty and the alternative covered transaction:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-3-i
paragraph.content: Has an annual percentage rate that cannot increase after consummation and has the same type of interest rate as the covered transaction with a prepayment penalty; for purposes of this paragraph (g), the term “type of interest rate” refers to whether a transaction:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-3-i-A
paragraph.content: Is a fixed-rate mortgage, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(iii); or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-3-i-B
paragraph.content: Is a step-rate mortgage, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(ii);

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-3-ii
paragraph.content: Has the same loan term as the loan term for the covered transaction with a prepayment penalty;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-3-iii
paragraph.content: Satisfies the periodic payment conditions under paragraph (e)(2)(i) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-3-iv
paragraph.content: Satisfies the points and fees conditions under paragraph (e)(2)(iii) of this section, based on the information known to the creditor at the time the transaction is offered; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-3-v
paragraph.content: Is a transaction for which the creditor has a good faith belief that the consumer likely qualifies, based on the information known to the creditor at the time the creditor offers the covered transaction without a prepayment penalty.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-4
paragraph.title: Offer through a mortgage broker.
paragraph.content: Offer through a mortgage broker. If the creditor offers a covered transaction with a prepayment penalty to the consumer through a mortgage broker, as defined in § 1026.36(a)(2), the creditor must:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-4-i
paragraph.content: Present the mortgage broker an alternative covered transaction without a prepayment penalty that satisfies the requirements of paragraph (g)(3) of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-4-ii
paragraph.content: Establish by agreement that the mortgage broker must present the consumer an alternative covered transaction without a prepayment penalty that satisfies the requirements of paragraph (g)(3) of this section, offered by:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-4-ii-A
paragraph.content: The creditor; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-4-ii-B
paragraph.content: Another creditor, if the transaction offered by the other creditor has a lower interest rate or a lower total dollar amount of discount points and origination points or fees.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-5
paragraph.title: Creditor that is a loan originator.
paragraph.content: Creditor that is a loan originator. If the creditor is a loan originator, as defined in § 1026.36(a)(1), and the creditor presents the consumer a covered transaction offered by a person to which the creditor would assign the covered transaction after consummation, the creditor must present the consumer an alternative covered transaction without a prepayment penalty that satisfies the requirements of paragraph (g)(3) of this section, offered by:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-5-i
paragraph.content: The assignee; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-5-ii
paragraph.content: Another person, if the transaction offered by the other person has a lower interest rate or a lower total dollar amount of origination discount points and points or fees.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-6
paragraph.title: Applicability.
paragraph.content: Applicability. This paragraph (g) applies only if a covered transaction is consummated with a prepayment penalty and is not violated if:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-6-i
paragraph.content: A covered transaction is consummated without a prepayment penalty; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-6-ii
paragraph.content: The creditor and consumer do not consummate a covered transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f
paragraph.title: Balloon-payment qualified mortgages made by certain creditors—
paragraph.content: Balloon-payment qualified mortgages made by certain creditors—

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1
paragraph.title: Exemption.
paragraph.content: Exemption. Notwithstanding paragraph (e)(2) of this section, a qualified mortgage may provide for a balloon payment, provided:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-i
paragraph.content: The loan satisfies the requirements for a qualified mortgage in paragraphs (e)(2)(i)(A), (e)(2)(ii), (e)(2)(iii), and (e)(2)(v) of this section, but without regard to the standards in appendix Q;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-ii
paragraph.content: The creditor determines at or before consummation that the consumer can make all of the scheduled payments under the terms of the legal obligation, as described in paragraph (f)(1)(iv) of this section, together with the consumer's monthly payments for all mortgage-related obligations and excluding the balloon payment, from the consumer's current or reasonably expected income or assets other than the dwelling that secures the loan;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iii
paragraph.content: The creditor considers at or before consummation the consumer's monthly debt-to-income ratio or residual income and verifies the debt obligations and income used to determine that ratio in accordance with paragraph (c)(7) of this section, except that the calculation of the payment on the covered transaction for purposes of determining the consumer's total monthly debt obligations in (c)(7)(i)(A) shall be determined in accordance with paragraph (f)(iv)(A) of this section, together with the consumer's monthly payments for all mortgage-related obligations and excluding the balloon payment;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iv
paragraph.content: The legal obligation provides for:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iv-A
paragraph.content: Scheduled payments that are substantially equal, calculated using an amortization period that does not exceed 30 years;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iv-B
paragraph.content: An interest rate that does not increase over the term of the loan; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iv-C
paragraph.content: A loan term of five years or longer.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-v
paragraph.content: The loan is not subject, at consummation, to a commitment to be acquired by another person, other than a person that satisfies the requirements of paragraph (f)(1)(vi) of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-vi
paragraph.content: The creditor satisfies the requirements stated in § 1026.35(b)(2)(iii)(A), (B), and (C).

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2
paragraph.title: Post-consummation transfer of balloon-payment qualified mortgage.
paragraph.content: Post-consummation transfer of balloon-payment qualified mortgage. A balloon-payment qualified mortgage, extended pursuant to paragraph (f)(1), immediately loses its status as a qualified mortgage under paragraph (f)(1) if legal title to the balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to another person except when:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-i
paragraph.content: The balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to another person three years or more after consummation of the balloon-payment qualified mortgage;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-ii
paragraph.content: The balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to a creditor that satisfies the requirements of paragraph (f)(1)(vi) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-iii
paragraph.content: The balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to another person pursuant to a capital restoration plan or other action under 12 U.S.C. 1831o, actions or instructions of any person acting as conservator, receiver or bankruptcy trustee, an order of a State or Federal governmental agency with jurisdiction to examine the creditor pursuant to State or Federal law, or an agreement between the creditor and such an agency; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-iv
paragraph.content: The balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred pursuant to a merger of the creditor with another person or acquisition of the creditor by another person or of another person by the creditor.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-h
paragraph.title: Evasion; open-end credit.
paragraph.content: Evasion; open-end credit. In connection with credit secured by a consumer's dwelling that does not meet the definition of open-end credit in § 1026.2(a)(20), a creditor shall not structure the loan as an open-end plan to evade the requirements of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-3
paragraph.title: Exemption from repayment ability requirements.
paragraph.content: Exemption from repayment ability requirements. A creditor is not required to comply with the requirements of paragraph (c) of this section if:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-3-i
paragraph.content: The conditions in paragraph (d)(2) of this section are met; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-3-ii
paragraph.content: The creditor has considered whether the standard mortgage likely will prevent a default by the consumer on the non-standard mortgage once the loan is recast.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-ii
paragraph.content: All compensation paid directly or indirectly by a consumer or creditor to a loan originator, as defined in § 1026.36(a)(1), that can be attributed to that transaction at the time the interest rate is set;

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i
paragraph.content: For purposes of this section, the term “loan originator” means a person who, in expectation of direct or indirect compensation or other monetary gain or for direct or indirect compensation or other monetary gain, performs any of the following activities: takes an application, offers, arranges, assists a consumer in obtaining or applying to obtain, negotiates, or otherwise obtains or makes an extension of consumer credit for another person; or through advertising or other means of communication represents to the public that such person can or will perform any of these activities. The term “loan originator” includes an employee, agent, or contractor of the creditor or loan originator organization if the employee, agent, or contractor meets this definition. The term “loan originator” includes a creditor that engages in loan origination activities if the creditor does not finance the transaction at consummation out of the creditor's own resources, including by drawing on a bona fide warehouse line of credit or out of deposits held by the creditor. All creditors that engage in any of the foregoing loan origination activities are loan originators for purposes of paragraphs (f) and (g) of this section. The term does not include:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-A
paragraph.content: A person who does not take a consumer credit application or offer or negotiate credit terms available from a creditor, but who performs purely administrative or clerical tasks on behalf of a person who does engage in such activities.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-B
paragraph.content: An employee of a manufactured home retailer who does not take a consumer credit application, offer or negotiate credit terms available from a creditor, or advise a consumer on credit terms (including rates, fees, and other costs) available from a creditor.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-C
paragraph.content: A person that performs only real estate brokerage activities and is licensed or registered in accordance with applicable State law, unless such person is compensated by a creditor or loan originator or by any agent of such creditor or loan originator for a particular consumer credit transaction subject to this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-D
paragraph.content: A seller financer that meets the criteria in paragraph (a)(4) or (a)(5) of this section, as applicable.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-E
paragraph.content: A servicer or servicer's employees, agents, and contractors who offer or negotiate terms for purposes of renegotiating, modifying, replacing, or subordinating principal of existing mortgages where consumers are behind in their payments, in default, or have a reasonable likelihood of defaulting or falling behind. This exception does not apply, however, to a servicer or servicer's employees, agents, and contractors who offer or negotiate a transaction that constitutes a refinancing under § 1026.20(a) or obligates a different consumer on the existing debt.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a
paragraph.title: Refinancings.
paragraph.content: Refinancings. A refinancing occurs when an existing obligation that was subject to this subpart is satisfied and replaced by a new obligation undertaken by the same consumer. A refinancing is a new transaction requiring new disclosures to the consumer. The new finance charge shall include any unearned portion of the old finance charge that is not credited to the existing obligation. The following shall not be treated as a refinancing:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a-1
paragraph.content: A renewal of a single payment obligation with no change in the original terms.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a-2
paragraph.content: A reduction in the annual percentage rate with a corresponding change in the payment schedule.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a-3
paragraph.content: An agreement involving a court proceeding.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a-4
paragraph.content: A change in the payment schedule or a change in collateral requirements as a result of the consumer's default or delinquency, unless the rate is increased, or the new amount financed exceeds the unpaid balance plus earned finance charge and premiums for continuation of insurance of the types described in § 1026.4(d).

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a-5
paragraph.content: The renewal of optional insurance purchased by the consumer and added to an existing transaction, if disclosures relating to the initial purchase were provided as required by this subpart.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b
paragraph.title: Assumptions.
paragraph.content: Assumptions. An assumption occurs when a creditor expressly agrees in writing with a subsequent consumer to accept that consumer as a primary obligor on an existing residential mortgage transaction. Before the assumption occurs, the creditor shall make new disclosures to the subsequent consumer, based on the remaining obligation. If the finance charge originally imposed on the existing obligation was an add-on or discount finance charge, the creditor need only disclose:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b-1
paragraph.content: The unpaid balance of the obligation assumed.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b-2
paragraph.content: The total charges imposed by the creditor in connection with the assumption.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b-3
paragraph.content: The information required to be disclosed under § 1026.18(k), (l), (m), and (n).

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b-4
paragraph.content: The annual percentage rate originally imposed on the obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b-5
paragraph.content: The payment schedule under § 1026.18(g) and the total of payments under § 1026.18(h) based on the remaining obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c
paragraph.title: Variable-rate adjustments.
paragraph.content: Variable-rate adjustments. Except as provided in paragraph (d) of this section, an adjustment to the interest rate with or without a corresponding adjustment to the payment in a variable-rate transaction subject to § 1026.19(b) is an event requiring new disclosures to the consumer. At least once each year during which an interest rate adjustment is implemented without an accompanying payment change, and at least 25, but no more than 120, calendar days before a payment at a new level is due, the following disclosures, as applicable, must be delivered or placed in the mail:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-1
paragraph.content: The current and prior interest rates.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2
paragraph.content: The index values upon which the current and prior interest rates are based.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-3
paragraph.content: The extent to which the creditor has foregone any increase in the interest rate.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-4
paragraph.content: The contractual effects of the adjustment, including the payment due after the adjustment is made, and a statement of the loan balance.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-5
paragraph.content: The payment, if different from that referred to in paragraph (c)(4) of this section, that would be required to fully amortize the loan at the new interest rate over the remainder of the loan term.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d
paragraph.content: Information provided in accordance with variable-rate subsequent disclosure regulations of other Federal agencies may be substituted for the disclosure required by paragraph (c) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i
paragraph.content: A covered transaction is not a qualified mortgage unless the transaction's total points and fees, as defined in § 1026.32(b)(1), do not exceed:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-A
paragraph.content: For a loan amount greater than or equal to $100,000 (indexed for inflation): 3 percent of the total loan amount;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-B
paragraph.content: For a loan amount greater than or equal to $60,000 (indexed for inflation) but less than $100,000 (indexed for inflation): $3,000 (indexed for inflation);

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-C
paragraph.content: For a loan amount greater than or equal to $20,000 (indexed for inflation) but less than $60,000 (indexed for inflation): 5 percent of the total loan amount;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-D
paragraph.content: For a loan amount greater than or equal to $12,500 (indexed for inflation) but less than $20,000 (indexed for inflation): $1,000 (indexed for inflation);

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-i-E
paragraph.content: For a loan amount less than $12,500 (indexed for inflation): 8 percent of the total loan amount.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1
paragraph.title: Exemption.
paragraph.content: Exemption. Notwithstanding paragraph (e)(2) of this section, a qualified mortgage may provide for a balloon payment, provided:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-i
paragraph.content: The loan satisfies the requirements for a qualified mortgage in paragraphs (e)(2)(i)(A), (e)(2)(ii), (e)(2)(iii), and (e)(2)(v) of this section, but without regard to the standards in appendix Q;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-ii
paragraph.content: The creditor determines at or before consummation that the consumer can make all of the scheduled payments under the terms of the legal obligation, as described in paragraph (f)(1)(iv) of this section, together with the consumer's monthly payments for all mortgage-related obligations and excluding the balloon payment, from the consumer's current or reasonably expected income or assets other than the dwelling that secures the loan;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iii
paragraph.content: The creditor considers at or before consummation the consumer's monthly debt-to-income ratio or residual income and verifies the debt obligations and income used to determine that ratio in accordance with paragraph (c)(7) of this section, except that the calculation of the payment on the covered transaction for purposes of determining the consumer's total monthly debt obligations in (c)(7)(i)(A) shall be determined in accordance with paragraph (f)(iv)(A) of this section, together with the consumer's monthly payments for all mortgage-related obligations and excluding the balloon payment;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iv
paragraph.content: The legal obligation provides for:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iv-A
paragraph.content: Scheduled payments that are substantially equal, calculated using an amortization period that does not exceed 30 years;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iv-B
paragraph.content: An interest rate that does not increase over the term of the loan; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iv-C
paragraph.content: A loan term of five years or longer.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-v
paragraph.content: The loan is not subject, at consummation, to a commitment to be acquired by another person, other than a person that satisfies the requirements of paragraph (f)(1)(vi) of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-vi
paragraph.content: The creditor satisfies the requirements stated in § 1026.35(b)(2)(iii)(A), (B), and (C).

paragraph.label: 1026-25-a
paragraph.title: General rule.
paragraph.content: General rule. A creditor shall retain evidence of compliance with this regulation, other than advertising requirements under §§ 1026.16 and 1026.24 and certain requirements for mortgage loans under paragraph (c) of this section, for two years after the date disclosures are required to be made or action is required to be taken. The administrative agencies responsible for enforcing the regulation may require a creditor under their jurisdictions to retain records for a longer period if necessary to carry out their enforcement responsibilities under section 108 of the Act.

paragraph.label: 1026-25-b
paragraph.title: Inspection of records.
paragraph.content: Inspection of records. A creditor shall permit the agency responsible for enforcing this part with respect to that creditor to inspect its relevant records for compliance.

paragraph.label: 1026-25-c
paragraph.content: Records related to certain requirements for mortgage loans.

paragraph.label: 1026-25-c-1
paragraph.content: [Reserved]

paragraph.label: 1026-25-c-2
paragraph.title: Records related to requirements for loan originator compensation.
paragraph.content: Records related to requirements for loan originator compensation. Notwithstanding paragraph (a) of this section, for transactions subject to § 1026.36:

paragraph.label: 1026-25-c-2-i
paragraph.content: A creditor shall maintain records sufficient to evidence all compensation it pays to a loan originator, as defined in § 1026.36(a)(1), and the compensation agreement that governs those payments for three years after the date of payment.

paragraph.label: 1026-25-c-2-ii
paragraph.content: A loan originator organization, as defined in § 1026.36(a)(1)(iii), shall maintain records sufficient to evidence all compensation it receives from a creditor, a consumer, or another person; all compensation it pays to any individual loan originator, as defined in § 1026.36(a)(1)(ii); and the compensation agreement that governs each such receipt or payment, for three years after the date of each such receipt or payment.

paragraph.label: 1026-25-c-3
paragraph.title: Records related to minimum standards for transactions secured by a dwelling.
paragraph.content: Records related to minimum standards for transactions secured by a dwelling. Notwithstanding paragraph (a) of this section, a creditor shall retain evidence of compliance with § 1026.43 of this regulation for three years after consummation of a transaction covered by that section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-i
paragraph.title: Non-standard mortgage.
paragraph.content: Non-standard mortgage. The term non-standard mortgage means a covered transaction that is:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-i-A
paragraph.content: An adjustable-rate mortgage, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(i), with an introductory fixed interest rate for a period of one year or longer;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-i-B
paragraph.content: An interest-only loan, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(iv); or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-i-C
paragraph.content: A negative amortization loan, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(7)(v).

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-i
paragraph.content: The loan satisfies the requirements for a qualified mortgage in paragraphs (e)(2)(i)(A), (e)(2)(ii), (e)(2)(iii), and (e)(2)(v) of this section, but without regard to the standards in appendix Q;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-2-i
paragraph.content: The creditor for the standard mortgage is the current holder of the existing non-standard mortgage or the servicer acting on behalf of the current holder;

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iv-B
paragraph.content: A county is “underserved” during a calendar year if, according to Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA) data for the preceding calendar year, no more than two creditors extended covered transactions, as defined in § 1026.43(b)(1), secured by a first lien, five or more times in the county. A creditor may rely as a safe harbor on the list of counties published by the Bureau to determine whether a county qualifies as “underserved” for a particular calendar year.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iv-A
paragraph.content: A county is “rural” during a calendar year if it is neither in a metropolitan statistical area nor in a micropolitan statistical area that is adjacent to a metropolitan statistical area, as those terms are defined by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget and as they are applied under currently applicable Urban Influence Codes (UICs), established by the United States Department of Agriculture's Economic Research Service (USDA-ERS). A creditor may rely as a safe harbor on the list of counties published by the Bureau to determine whether a county qualifies as “rural” for a particular calendar year.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph (b)(2)(v) of this section, an escrow account need not be established for a transaction if, at the time of consummation:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-A
paragraph.content: During the preceding calendar year, the creditor extended more than 50 percent of its total covered transactions, as defined by § 1026.43(b)(1), secured by a first lien, on properties that are located in counties that are either “rural” or “underserved,” as set forth in paragraph (b)(2)(iv) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-B
paragraph.content: During the preceding calendar year, the creditor and its affiliates together originated 500 or fewer covered transactions, as defined by § 1026.43(b)(1), secured by a first lien; and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-C
paragraph.content: As of the end of the preceding calendar year, the creditor had total assets of less than $2,000,000,000; this asset threshold shall adjust automatically each year, based on the year-to-year change in the average of the Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers, not seasonally adjusted, for each 12-month period ending in November, with rounding to the nearest million dollars (see comment 35(b)(2)(iii)-1.iii for the current threshold); and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D
paragraph.content: Neither the creditor nor its affiliate maintains an escrow account of the type described in paragraph (b)(1) of this section for any extension of consumer credit secured by real property or a dwelling that the creditor or its affiliate currently services, other than:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D-1
paragraph.content: Escrow accounts established for first-lien higher-priced mortgage loans on or after April 1, 2010, and before June 1, 2013; or

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D-2
paragraph.content: Escrow accounts established after consummation as an accommodation to distressed consumers to assist such consumers in avoiding default or foreclosure.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-v
paragraph.content: The loan is not subject, at consummation, to a commitment to be acquired by another person, other than a person that satisfies the requirements of paragraph (f)(1)(vi) of this section; and

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-a-Interp-5-i
interpParagraph.content: General. For purposes of § 1026.36, compensation is defined in § 1026.36(a)(3) as salaries, commissions, and any financial or similar incentive. For example, the term “compensation” includes:

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-a-Interp-5-i-A
interpParagraph.content: An annual or other periodic bonus; or

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-a-Interp-5-i-B
interpParagraph.content: Awards of merchandise, services, trips, or similar prizes.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a
paragraph.title: Loan originator and mortgage broker defined
paragraph.content: Definitions.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1
paragraph.title: Loan originator.
paragraph.content: Loan originator.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i
paragraph.content: For purposes of this section, the term “loan originator” means a person who, in expectation of direct or indirect compensation or other monetary gain or for direct or indirect compensation or other monetary gain, performs any of the following activities: takes an application, offers, arranges, assists a consumer in obtaining or applying to obtain, negotiates, or otherwise obtains or makes an extension of consumer credit for another person; or through advertising or other means of communication represents to the public that such person can or will perform any of these activities. The term “loan originator” includes an employee, agent, or contractor of the creditor or loan originator organization if the employee, agent, or contractor meets this definition. The term “loan originator” includes a creditor that engages in loan origination activities if the creditor does not finance the transaction at consummation out of the creditor's own resources, including by drawing on a bona fide warehouse line of credit or out of deposits held by the creditor. All creditors that engage in any of the foregoing loan origination activities are loan originators for purposes of paragraphs (f) and (g) of this section. The term does not include:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-A
paragraph.content: A person who does not take a consumer credit application or offer or negotiate credit terms available from a creditor, but who performs purely administrative or clerical tasks on behalf of a person who does engage in such activities.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-B
paragraph.content: An employee of a manufactured home retailer who does not take a consumer credit application, offer or negotiate credit terms available from a creditor, or advise a consumer on credit terms (including rates, fees, and other costs) available from a creditor.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-C
paragraph.content: A person that performs only real estate brokerage activities and is licensed or registered in accordance with applicable State law, unless such person is compensated by a creditor or loan originator or by any agent of such creditor or loan originator for a particular consumer credit transaction subject to this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-D
paragraph.content: A seller financer that meets the criteria in paragraph (a)(4) or (a)(5) of this section, as applicable.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-E
paragraph.content: A servicer or servicer's employees, agents, and contractors who offer or negotiate terms for purposes of renegotiating, modifying, replacing, or subordinating principal of existing mortgages where consumers are behind in their payments, in default, or have a reasonable likelihood of defaulting or falling behind. This exception does not apply, however, to a servicer or servicer's employees, agents, and contractors who offer or negotiate a transaction that constitutes a refinancing under § 1026.20(a) or obligates a different consumer on the existing debt.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-ii
paragraph.content: An “individual loan originator” is a natural person who meets the definition of “loan originator” in paragraph (a)(1)(i) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-iii
paragraph.content: A “loan originator organization” is any loan originator, as defined in paragraph (a)(1)(i) of this section, that is not an individual loan originator.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-2
paragraph.title: Mortgage broker.
paragraph.content: Mortgage broker. For purposes of this section, a mortgage broker with respect to a particular transaction is any loan originator that is not an employee of the creditor.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-3
paragraph.title: Compensation.
paragraph.content: Compensation. The term “compensation” includes salaries, commissions, and any financial or similar incentive.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-4
paragraph.title: Seller financers; three properties.
paragraph.content: Seller financers; three properties. A person (as defined in § 1026.2(a)(22)) that meets all of the following criteria is not a loan originator under paragraph (a)(1) of this section:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-4-i
paragraph.content: The person provides seller financing for the sale of three or fewer properties in any 12-month period to purchasers of such properties, each of which is owned by the person and serves as security for the financing.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-4-ii
paragraph.content: The person has not constructed, or acted as a contractor for the construction of, a residence on the property in the ordinary course of business of the person.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-4-iii
paragraph.content: The person provides seller financing that meets the following requirements:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-4-iii-A
paragraph.content: The financing is fully amortizing.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-4-iii-B
paragraph.content: The financing is one that the person determines in good faith the consumer has a reasonable ability to repay.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-4-iii-C
paragraph.content: The financing has a fixed rate or an adjustable rate that is adjustable after five or more years, subject to reasonable annual and lifetime limitations on interest rate increases. If the financing agreement has an adjustable rate, the rate is determined by the addition of a margin to an index rate and is subject to reasonable rate adjustment limitations. The index the adjustable rate is based on is a widely available index such as indices for U.S. Treasury securities or LIBOR.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5
paragraph.title: Seller financers; one property.
paragraph.content: Seller financers; one property. A natural person, estate, or trust that meets all of the following criteria is not a loan originator under paragraph (a)(1) of this section:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5-i
paragraph.content: The natural person, estate, or trust provides seller financing for the sale of only one property in any 12-month period to purchasers of such property, which is owned by the natural person, estate, or trust and serves as security for the financing.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5-ii
paragraph.content: The natural person, estate, or trust has not constructed, or acted as a contractor for the construction of, a residence on the property in the ordinary course of business of the person.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5-iii
paragraph.content: The natural person, estate, or trust provides seller financing that meets the following requirements:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5-iii-A
paragraph.content: The financing has a repayment schedule that does not result in negative amortization.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-5-iii-B
paragraph.content: The financing has a fixed rate or an adjustable rate that is adjustable after five or more years, subject to reasonable annual and lifetime limitations on interest rate increases. If the financing agreement has an adjustable rate, the rate is determined by the addition of a margin to an index rate and is subject to reasonable rate adjustment limitations. The index the adjustable rate is based on is a widely available index such as indices for U.S. Treasury securities or LIBOR.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-b
paragraph.content: Scope. Paragraph (c) of this section applies to closed-end consumer credit transactions secured by a consumer's principal dwelling. Paragraphs (d), (e), (f), (g), (h), and (i) of this section apply to closed-end consumer credit transactions secured by a dwelling. This section does not apply to a home equity line of credit subject to § 1026.40, except that paragraphs (h) and (i) of this section apply to such credit when secured by the consumer's principal dwelling. Paragraphs (d), (e), (f), (g), (h), and (i) of this section do not apply to a loan that is secured by a consumer's interest in a timeshare plan described in 11 U.S.C. 101(53D).

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d
paragraph.title: Prohibited payments to loan originators
paragraph.content: Prohibited payments to loan originators —

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1
paragraph.title: Payments based on transaction terms or conditions.
paragraph.content: Payments based on a term of a transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-i
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph (d)(1)(iii) or (iv) of this section, in connection with a consumer credit transaction secured by a dwelling, no loan originator shall receive and no person shall pay to a loan originator, directly or indirectly, compensation in an amount that is based on a term of a transaction, the terms of multiple transactions by an individual loan originator, or the terms of multiple transactions by multiple individual loan originators. If a loan originator's compensation is based in whole or in part on a factor that is a proxy for a term of a transaction, the loan originator's compensation is based on a term of a transaction. A factor that is not itself a term of a transaction is a proxy for a term of the transaction if the factor consistently varies with that term over a significant number of transactions, and the loan originator has the ability, directly or indirectly, to add, drop, or change the factor in originating the transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-ii
paragraph.content: For purposes of this paragraph (d)(1) only, a “term of a transaction” is any right or obligation of the parties to a credit transaction. The amount of credit extended is not a term of a transaction or a proxy for a term of a transaction, provided that compensation received by or paid to a loan originator, directly or indirectly, is based on a fixed percentage of the amount of credit extended; however, such compensation may be subject to a minimum or maximum dollar amount.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iii
paragraph.content: An individual loan originatoroan originator may receive, and a person may pay to an individual loan originatordual loan originator, compensation in the form of a contribution to a defined contribution plan that is a designated tax-advantaged plan or a benefit under a defined benefit plan that is a designated tax-advantaged plan. In the case of a contribution to a defined contribution plan, the contribution shall not be directly or indirectly based on the terms of that individual loan originator's transactions. As used in this paragraph (d)(1)(iii), “designated tax-advantaged plan” means any plan that meets the requirements of Internal Revenue Code section 401(a), 26 U.S.C. 401(a); employee annuity plan described in Internal Revenue Code section 403(a), 26 U.S.C. 403(a); simple retirement account, as defined in Internal Revenue Code section 408(p), 26 U.S.C. 408(p); simplified employee pension described in Internal Revenue Code section 408(k), 26 U.S.C. 408(k); annuity contract described in Internal Revenue Code section 403(b), 26 U.S.C. 403(b); or eligible deferred compensation plan, as defined in Internal Revenue Code section 457(b), 26 U.S.C. 457(b).

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv
paragraph.content: An individual loan originator may receive, and a person may pay to an individual loan originator, compensation under a non-deferred profits-based compensation plan (i.e., any arrangement for the payment of non-deferred compensation that is determined with reference to the profits of the person from mortgage-related business), provided that:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-A
paragraph.content: The compensation paid to an individual loan originator pursuant to this paragraph (d)(1)(iv) is not directly or indirectly based on the terms of that individual loan originator's transactions that are subject to this paragraph (d); and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-B
paragraph.content: At least one of the following conditions is satisfied:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-B-1
paragraph.content: The compensation paid to an individual loan originator pursuant to this paragraph (d)(1)(iv) does not, in the aggregate, exceed 10 percent of the individual loan originator's total compensation corresponding to the time period for which the compensation under the non-deferred profits-based compensation plan is paid; or

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-B-2
paragraph.content: The individual loan originator was a loan originator for ten or fewer transactions subject to this paragraph (d) consummated during the 12-month period preceding the date of the compensation determination.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2
paragraph.title: Payments by persons other than consumer.
paragraph.content: Payments by persons other than consumer.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i
paragraph.content: Dual compensation.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-A
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph (d)(2)(i)(C) of this section, if any loan originator receives compensation directly from a consumer in a consumer credit transaction secured by a dwelling:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-A-1
paragraph.content: No loan originator shall receive compensation, directly or indirectly, from any person other than the consumer in connection with the transaction; and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-A-2
paragraph.content: No person who knows or has reason to know of the consumer-paid compensation to the loan originator (other than the consumer) shall pay any compensation to a loan originator, directly or indirectly, in connection with the transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-B
paragraph.content: Compensation received directly from a consumer includes payments to a loan originator made pursuant to an agreement between the consumer and a person other than the creditor or its affiliates, under which such other person agrees to provide funds toward the consumer's costs of the transaction (including loan originator compensation).

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-i-C
paragraph.content: If a loan originator organization receives compensation directly from a consumer in connection with a transaction, the loan originator organization may pay compensation to an individual loan originator, and the individual loan originator may receive compensation from the loan originator organization, subject to paragraph (d)(1) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-2-ii
paragraph.content: Exemption. A payment to a loan originator that is otherwise prohibited by section 129B(c)(2)(A) of the Truth in Lending Act is nevertheless permitted pursuant to section 129B(c)(2)(B) of the Act, regardless of whether the consumer makes any upfront payment of discount points, origination points, or fees, as described in section 129B(c)(2)(B)(ii) of the Act, as long as the loan originator does not receive any compensation directly from the consumer as described in section 129B(c)(2)(B)(i) of the Act.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-3
paragraph.title: Affiliates.
paragraph.content: Affiliates. For purposes of this paragraph (d), affiliates shall be treated as a single “person.”

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a
paragraph.title: General rule
paragraph.content: General rule —

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-1-i
paragraph.title: Consideration of ability to pay.
paragraph.content: Consideration of ability to pay. A card issuer must not open a credit card account for a consumer under an open-end (not home-secured) consumer credit plan, or increase any credit limit applicable to such account, unless the card issuer considers the consumer's ability to make the required minimum periodic payments under the terms of the account based on the consumer's income or assets and the consumer's current obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-1-ii
paragraph.title: Reasonable policies and procedures.
paragraph.content: Reasonable policies and procedures. Card issuers must establish and maintain reasonable written policies and procedures to consider the consumer's ability to make the required minimum payments under the terms of the account based on a consumer's income or assets and a consumer's current obligations. Reasonable policies and procedures include treating any income and assets to which the consumer has a reasonable expectation of access as the consumer's income or assets, or limiting consideration of the consumer's income or assets to the consumer's independent income and assets. Reasonable policies and procedures also include consideration of at least one of the following: The ratio of debt obligations to income; the ratio of debt obligations to assets; or the income the consumer will have after paying debt obligations. It would be unreasonable for a card issuer not to review any information about a consumer's income or assets and current obligations, or to issue a credit card to a consumer who does not have any income or assets.

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-2
paragraph.title: Minimum periodic payments
paragraph.content: Minimum periodic payments —

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-2-i
paragraph.title: Reasonable method.
paragraph.content: Reasonable method. For purposes of paragraph (a)(1) of this section, a card issuer must use a reasonable method for estimating the minimum periodic payments the consumer would be required to pay under the terms of the account.

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-2-ii
paragraph.title: Safe harbor.
paragraph.content: Safe harbor. A card issuer complies with paragraph (a)(2)(i) of this section if it estimates required minimum periodic payments using the following method:

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-2-ii-A
paragraph.content: The card issuer assumes utilization, from the first day of the billing cycle, of the full credit line that the issuer is considering offering to the consumer; and

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-2-ii-B
paragraph.content: The card issuer uses a minimum payment formula employed by the issuer for the product the issuer is considering offering to the consumer or, in the case of an existing account, the minimum payment formula that currently applies to that account, provided that:

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-2-ii-B-1
paragraph.content: If the applicable minimum payment formula includes interest charges, the card issuer estimates those charges using an interest rate that the issuer is considering offering to the consumer for purchases or, in the case of an existing account, the interest rate that currently applies to purchases; and

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-2-ii-B-2
paragraph.content: If the applicable minimum payment formula includes mandatory fees, the card issuer must assume that such fees have been charged to the account.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f
paragraph.content: Loan originator qualification requirements. A loan originator for a consumer creditmer credit transaction secured by a dwelling must, when required by applicable State or Federal law, be registered and licensed in accordance with those laws, including the Secure and Fair Enforcement for Mortgage Licensing Act of 2008 (SAFE Act, 12 U.S.C. 5102 et seq.), its implementing regulations (12 CFR part 1007 or part 1008), and State SAFE Act implementing law. To comply with this paragraph (f), a loan originator organization that is not a government agency or State housing finance agency must:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-1
paragraph.content: Comply with all applicable State law requirements for legal existence and foreign qualification;

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-2
paragraph.content: Ensure that each individual loan originator who works for the loan originator organization is licensed or registered to the extent the individual is required to be licensed or registered under the SAFE Act, its implementing regulations, and State SAFE Act implementing law before the individual acts as a loan originator in a consumer credit transaction secured by a dwelling; and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3
paragraph.content: For each of its individual loan originator employees who is not required to be licensed and is not licensed as a loan originator pursuant to § 1008.103 of this chapter or State SAFE Act implementing law:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-i
paragraph.content: Obtain for any individual whom the loan originator organization hired on or after January 10, 2014 (or whom the loan originator organization hired before this date but for whom there were no applicable statutory or regulatory background standards in effect at the time of hire or before January 10, 2014, used to screen the individual) and for any individual regardless of when hired who, based on reliable information known to the loan originator organization, likely does not meet the standards under § 1026.36(f)(3)(ii), before the individual acts as a loan originator in a consumer credit transaction secured by a dwelling:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-i-A
paragraph.content: A criminal background check through the Nationwide Mortgage Licensing System and Registry (NMLSR) or, in the case of an individual loan originator who is not a registered loan originator under the NMLSR, a criminal background check from a law enforcement agency or commercial service;

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-i-B
paragraph.content: A credit report from a consumer reporting agency described in section 603(p) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act (15 U.S.C. 1681a(p)) secured, where applicable, in compliance with the requirements of section 604(b) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. 1681b(b); and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-i-C
paragraph.content: Information from the NMLSR about any administrative, civil, or criminal findings by any government jurisdiction or, in the case of an individual loan originator who is not a registered loan originator under the NMLSR, such information from the individual loan originator;

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii
paragraph.content: Determine on the basis of the information obtained pursuant to paragraph (f)(3)(i) of this section and any other information reasonably available to the loan originator organization, for any individual whom the loan originator organization hired on or after January 10, 2014 (or whom the loan originator organization hired before this date but for whom there were no applicable statutory or regulatory background standards in effect at the time of hire or before January 10, 2014, used to screen the individual) and for any individual regardless of when hired who, based on reliable information known to the loan originator organization, likely does not meet the standards under this § 1026.36(f)(3)(ii), before the individual acts as a loan originator in a consumer credit transaction secured by a dwelling, that the individual loan originator:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-A-1
paragraph.content: Has not been convicted of, or pleaded guilty or nolo contendere to, a felony in a domestic or military court during the preceding seven-year period or, in the case of a felony involving an act of fraud, dishonesty, a breach of trust, or money laundering, at any time;

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-A-2
paragraph.content: For purposes of this paragraph (f)(3)(ii)(A):

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-A-2-i
paragraph.content: A crime is a felony only if at the time of conviction it was classified as a felony under the law of the jurisdiction under which the individual was convicted;

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-A-2-ii
paragraph.content: Expunged convictions and pardoned convictions do not render an individual unqualified; and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-A-2-iii
paragraph.content: A conviction or plea of guilty or nolo contendere does not render an individual unqualified under this § 1026.36(f) if the loan originator organization has obtained consent to employ the individual from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (or the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, as applicable) pursuant to section 19 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act (FDIA), 12 U.S.C. 1829, the National Credit Union Administration pursuant to section 205 of the Federal Credit Union Act (FCUA), 12 U.S.C. 1785(d), or the Farm Credit Administration pursuant to section 5.65(d) of the Farm Credit Act of 1971 (FCA), 12 U.S.C. 227a-14(d), notwithstanding the bars posed with respect to that conviction or plea by the FDIA, FCUA, and FCA, as applicable; and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-ii-B
paragraph.content: Has demonstrated financial responsibility, character, and general fitness such as to warrant a determination that the individual loan originator will operate honestly, fairly, and efficiently; and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-3-iii
paragraph.content: Provide periodic training covering Federal and State law requirements that apply to the individual loan originator's loan origination activities.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-h
paragraph.title: Prohibition on mandatory arbitration clauses and waivers of certain consumer rights.
paragraph.content: Prohibition on mandatory arbitration clauses and waivers of certain consumer rights.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-h-1
paragraph.title: Arbitration.
paragraph.content: Arbitration. A contract or other agreement for a consumer credit transaction secured by a dwelling (including a home equity line of credit secured by the consumer's principal dwelling) may not include terms that require arbitration or any other non-judicial procedure to resolve any controversy or settle any claims arising out of the transaction. This prohibition does not limit a consumer and creditor or any assignee from agreeing, after a dispute or claim under the transaction arises, to settle or use arbitration or other non-judicial procedure to resolve that dispute or claim.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-h-2
paragraph.title: No waivers of Federal statutory causes of action.
paragraph.content: No waivers of Federal statutory causes of action. A contract or other agreement relating to a consumer credit transaction secured by a dwelling (including a home equity line of credit secured by the consumer's principal dwelling) may not be applied or interpreted to bar a consumer from bringing a claim in court pursuant to any provision of law for damages or other relief in connection with any alleged violation of any Federal law. This prohibition does not limit a consumer and creditor or any assignee from agreeing, after a dispute or claim under the transaction arises, to settle or use arbitration or other non-judicial procedure to resolve that dispute or claim.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-j
paragraph.title: Policies and procedures to ensure and monitor compliance.
paragraph.content: Policies and procedures to ensure and monitor compliance.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-j-1
paragraph.content: A depository institution must establish and maintain written policies and procedures reasonably designed to ensure and monitor the compliance of the depository institution, its employees, its subsidiaries, and its subsidiaries' employees with the requirements of paragraphs (d), (e), (f), and (g) of this section. These written policies and procedures must be appropriate to the nature, size, complexity, and scope of the mortgage lending activities of the depository institution and its subsidiaries.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-j-2
paragraph.content: For purposes of this paragraph (j), “depository institution” has the meaning in section 1503(2) of the SAFE Act, 12 U.S.C. 5102(2). For purposes of this paragraph (j), “subsidiary” has the meaning in section 3 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act, 12 U.S.C. 1813.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-6-ii
paragraph.content: A home equity line of credit subject to § 1026.40, by using the periodic payment required under the terms of the plan and the amount of credit to be drawn at or before consummation of the covered transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-B-2
paragraph.content: The individual loan originator was a loan originator for ten or fewer transactions subject to this paragraph (d) consummated during the 12-month period preceding the date of the compensation determination.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iii
paragraph.content: For which the total points and fees payable in connection with the loan do not exceed the amounts specified in paragraph (e)(3) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-iv
paragraph.content: Premiums or other charges payable at or before consummation for any credit life, credit disability, credit unemployment, or credit property insurance, or any other life, accident, health, or loss-of-income insurance for which the creditor is a beneficiary, or any payments directly or indirectly for any debt cancellation or suspension agreement or contract;

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-B-1
paragraph.content: The compensation paid to an individual loan originator pursuant to this paragraph (d)(1)(iv) does not, in the aggregate, exceed 10 percent of the individual loan originator's total compensation corresponding to the time period for which the compensation under the non-deferred profits-based compensation plan is paid; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-2
paragraph.title: Limits on prepayment penalties.
paragraph.content: Limits on prepayment penalties. A prepayment penalty:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-2-i
paragraph.content: Must not apply after the three-year period following consummation; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-2-ii
paragraph.content: Must not exceed the following percentages of the amount of the outstanding loan balance prepaid:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-2-ii-A
paragraph.content: 2 percent, if incurred during the first two years following consummation; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-2-ii-B
paragraph.content: 1 percent, if incurred during the third year following consummation.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-viii
paragraph.content: The consumer's credit history.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4
paragraph.title: Qualified mortgage defined—special rules
paragraph.content: Qualified mortgage defined—special rules —

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-i
paragraph.title: General.
paragraph.content: General. Notwithstanding paragraph (e)(2) of this section, a qualified mortgage is a covered transaction that satisfies:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-i-A
paragraph.content: The requirements of paragraphs (e)(2)(i) through (iii) of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-i-B
paragraph.content: One or more of the criteria in paragraph (e)(4)(ii) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii
paragraph.title: Eligible loans.
paragraph.content: Eligible loans. A qualified mortgage under this paragraph (e)(4) must be one of the following at consummation:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-A
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-A-1
paragraph.content: To be purchased or guaranteed by the Federal National Mortgage Association or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation operating under the conservatorship or receivership of the Federal Housing Finance Agency pursuant to section 1367(a) of the Federal Housing Enterprises Financial Safety and Soundness Act of 1992 (12 U.S.C. 4617(a)); or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-A-2
paragraph.content: To be purchased or guaranteed by any limited-life regulatory entity succeeding the charter of either the Federal National Mortgage Association or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation pursuant to section 1367(i) of the Federal Housing Enterprises Financial Safety and Soundness Act of 1992 (12 U.S.C. 4617(i));

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-B
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible to be insured by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development under the National Housing Act (12 U.S.C. 1707 et seq.);

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-C
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible to be guaranteed the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-D
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible to be guaranteed by the U.S. Department of Agriculture pursuant to 42 U.S.C. 1472(h); or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-E
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible to be insured by the Rural Housing Service.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-iii
paragraph.title: Sunset of special rules.
paragraph.content: Sunset of special rules.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-iii-A
paragraph.content: Each respective special rule described in paragraph (e)(4)(ii)(B), (C), (D), or (E) of this section shall expire on the effective date of a rule issued by each respective agency pursuant to its authority under TILA section 129C(b)(3)(ii) to define a qualified mortgage.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-iii-B
paragraph.content: Unless otherwise expired under paragraph (e)(4)(iii)(A) of this section, the special rules in this paragraph (e)(4) are available only for covered transactions consummated on or before January 10, 2021.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-A
paragraph.content: A loan with a balloon payment, as defined in § 1026.18(s)(5)(i), using:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-A-1
paragraph.content: The maximum payment scheduled during the first five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment will be due for a loan that is not a higher-priced covered transaction; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-ii-A-2
paragraph.content: The maximum payment in the payment schedule, including any balloon payment, for a higher-priced covered transaction;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-1
paragraph.title: Safe harbor and presumption of compliance—
paragraph.content: Safe harbor and presumption of compliance—

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-1-i
paragraph.title: Safe harbor for transactions that are not higher-priced covered transactions.
paragraph.content: Safe harbor for transactions that are not higher-priced covered transactions. A creditor or assignee of a qualified mortgage, as defined in paragraphs (e)(2), (e)(4), or (f) of this section, that is not a higher-priced covered transaction, as defined in paragraph (b)(4) of this section, complies with the repayment ability requirements of paragraph (c) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-1-ii
paragraph.title: Presumption of compliance for higher-priced covered transactions.
paragraph.content: Presumption of compliance for higher-priced covered transactions.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-1-ii-A
paragraph.content: A creditor or assignee of a qualified mortgage, as defined in paragraphs (e)(2), (e)(4), or (f) of this section, that is a higher-priced covered transaction, as defined in paragraph (b)(4) of this section, is presumed to comply with the repayment ability requirements of paragraph (c) of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-1-ii-B
paragraph.content: To rebut the presumption of compliance described in paragraph (e)(1)(ii)(A) of this section, it must be proven that, despite meeting the requirements of paragraphs (e)(2), (e)(4), or (f) of this section, the creditor did not make a reasonable and good faith determination of the consumer's repayment ability at the time of consummation, by showing that the consumer's income, debt obligations, alimony, child support, and the consumer's monthly payment (including mortgage-related obligations) on the covered transaction and on any simultaneous loans of which the creditor was aware at consummation would leave the consumer with insufficient residual income or assets other than the value of the dwelling (including any real property attached to the dwelling) that secures the loan with which to meet living expenses, including any recurring and material non-debt obligations of which the creditor was aware at the time of consummation.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4
paragraph.title: Repayment ability.
paragraph.content: Repayment ability. Extend credit subject to § 1026.32 to a consumer based on the value of the consumer's collateral without regard to the consumer's repayment ability as of consummation, including the consumer's current and reasonably expected income, employment, assets other than the collateral, current obligations, and mortgage-related obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-i
paragraph.title: Mortgage-related obligations.
paragraph.content: Mortgage-related obligations. For purposes of this paragraph (a)(4), mortgage-related obligations are expected property taxes, premiums for mortgage-related insurance required by the creditor as set forth in § 1026.35(b), and similar expenses.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-ii
paragraph.title: Verification of repayment ability.
paragraph.content: Verification of repayment ability. Under this paragraph (a)(4) a creditor must verify the consumer's repayment ability as follows:

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-ii-A
paragraph.content: A creditor must verify amounts of income or assets that it relies on to determine repayment ability, including expected income or assets, by the consumer's Internal Revenue Service Form W-2, tax returns, payroll receipts, financial institution records, or other third-party documents that provide reasonably reliable evidence of the consumer's income or assets.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-ii-B
paragraph.content: Notwithstanding paragraph (a)(4)(ii)(A), a creditor has not violated paragraph (a)(4)(ii) if the amounts of income and assets that the creditor relied upon in determining repayment ability are not materially greater than the amounts of the consumer's income or assets that the creditor could have verified pursuant to paragraph (a)(4)(ii)(A) at the time the loan was consummated.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-ii-C
paragraph.content: A creditor must verify the consumer's current obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iii
paragraph.title: Presumption of compliance.
paragraph.content: Presumption of compliance. A creditor is presumed to have complied with this paragraph (a)(4) with respect to a transaction if the creditor:

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iii-A
paragraph.content: Verifies the consumer's repayment ability as provided in paragraph (a)(4)(ii);

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iii-B
paragraph.content: Determines the consumer's repayment ability using the largest payment of principal and interest scheduled in the first seven years following consummation and taking into account current obligations and mortgage-related obligations as defined in paragraph (a)(4)(i); and

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iii-C
paragraph.content: Assesses the consumer's repayment ability taking into account at least one of the following: The ratio of total debt obligations to income, or the income the consumer will have after paying debt obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iv
paragraph.title: Exclusions from presumption of compliance.
paragraph.content: Exclusions from presumption of compliance. Notwithstanding the previous paragraph, no presumption of compliance is available for a transaction for which:

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iv-A
paragraph.content: The regular periodic payments for the first seven years would cause the principal balance to increase; or

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iv-B
paragraph.content: The term of the loan is less than seven years and the regular periodic payments when aggregated do not fully amortize the outstanding principal balance.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-v
paragraph.title: Exemption.
paragraph.content: Exemption. This paragraph (a)(4) does not apply to temporary or “bridge” loans with terms of twelve months or less, such as a loan to purchase a new dwelling where the consumer plans to sell a current dwelling within twelve months.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2
paragraph.title: Post-consummation transfer of balloon-payment qualified mortgage.
paragraph.content: Post-consummation transfer of balloon-payment qualified mortgage. A balloon-payment qualified mortgage, extended pursuant to paragraph (f)(1), immediately loses its status as a qualified mortgage under paragraph (f)(1) if legal title to the balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to another person except when:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-i
paragraph.content: The balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to another person three years or more after consummation of the balloon-payment qualified mortgage;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-ii
paragraph.content: The balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to a creditor that satisfies the requirements of paragraph (f)(1)(vi) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-iii
paragraph.content: The balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred to another person pursuant to a capital restoration plan or other action under 12 U.S.C. 1831o, actions or instructions of any person acting as conservator, receiver or bankruptcy trustee, an order of a State or Federal governmental agency with jurisdiction to examine the creditor pursuant to State or Federal law, or an agreement between the creditor and such an agency; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-2-iv
paragraph.content: The balloon-payment qualified mortgage is sold, assigned, or otherwise transferred pursuant to a merger of the creditor with another person or acquisition of the creditor by another person or of another person by the creditor.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-6
paragraph.title: Applicability.
paragraph.content: Applicability. This paragraph (g) applies only if a covered transaction is consummated with a prepayment penalty and is not violated if:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-6-i
paragraph.content: A covered transaction is consummated without a prepayment penalty; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-6-ii
paragraph.content: The creditor and consumer do not consummate a covered transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-1
paragraph.title: Repayment ability.
paragraph.content: Requirement to escrow for property taxes and insurance. Except as provided in paragraph (b)(2) of this section, a creditor may not extend a higher-priced mortgage loan secured by a first lien on a consuconsumer's principal dwelling unless an escrow account is established before consummation for payment of property taxes and premiums for mortgage-related insurance required by the creditor, such as insurance against loss of or damage to property, or against liability arising out of the ownership or use of the property, or insurance protecting the creditor against the consumer's default or other credit loss. For purposes of this paragraph (b), the term “escrow account” has the same meaning as under Regulation X (12 CFR 1024.17(b)), as amended.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iv
paragraph.content: The legal obligation provides for:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iv-A
paragraph.content: Scheduled payments that are substantially equal, calculated using an amortization period that does not exceed 30 years;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iv-B
paragraph.content: An interest rate that does not increase over the term of the loan; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iv-C
paragraph.content: A loan term of five years or longer.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3
paragraph.title: Escrows
paragraph.content: Cancellation—

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-i
paragraph.title: Failure to escrow for property taxes and insurance.
paragraph.content: General. Except as provided in paragraph (b)(3)(ii) of this section, a creditor or servicer may cancel an escrow account required in paragraph (b)(1) of this section only upon the earlier of:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-i-A
paragraph.content: Termination of the underlying debt obligation; or

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-i-B
paragraph.content: Receipt no earlier than five years after consummation of a consumer's request to cancel the escrow account.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-ii
paragraph.title: Exemptions for loans secured by shares in a cooperative and for certain condominium units.
paragraph.content: Delayed cancellation. Notwithstanding paragraph (b)(3)(i) of this section, a creditor or servicer shall not cancel an escrow account pursuant to a consumer's request described in paragraph (b)(3)(i)(B) of this section unless the following conditions are satisfied:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-ii-A
paragraph.content: The unpaid principal balance is less than 80 percent of the original value of the property securing the underlying debt obligation; and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-3-ii-B
paragraph.content: The consumer currently is not delinquent or in default on the underlying debt obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2
paragraph.title: Prepayment penalties.
paragraph.content: Exemptions. Notwithstanding paragraph (b)(1) of this section:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-i
paragraph.content: An escrow account need not be established for:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-i-A
paragraph.content: A transaction secured by shares in a cooperative;

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-i-B
paragraph.content: A transaction to finance the initial construction of a dwelling;

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-i-C
paragraph.content: A temporary or “bridge” loan with a loan term of twelve months or less, such as a loan to purchase a new dwelling where the consumer plans to sell a current dwelling within twelve months; or

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-i-D
paragraph.content: A reverse mortgage transaction subject to § 1026.33(c).

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-ii
paragraph.content: Insurance premiums described in paragraph (b)(1) of this section need not be included in escrow accounts for loans secured by dwellings in condominiums, planned unit developments, or other common interest communities in which dwelling ownership requires participation in a governing association, where the governing association has an obligation to the dwelling owners to maintain a master policy insuring all dwellings.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph (b)(2)(v) of this section, an escrow account need not be established for a transaction if, at the time of consummation:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-A
paragraph.content: During the preceding calendar year, the creditor extended more than 50 percent of its total covered transactions, as defined by § 1026.43(b)(1), secured by a first lien, on properties that are located in counties that are either “rural” or “underserved,” as set forth in paragraph (b)(2)(iv) of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-B
paragraph.content: During the preceding calendar year, the creditor and its affiliates together originated 500 or fewer covered transactions, as defined by § 1026.43(b)(1), secured by a first lien; and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-C
paragraph.content: As of the end of the preceding calendar year, the creditor had total assets of less than $2,000,000,000; this asset threshold shall adjust automatically each year, based on the year-to-year change in the average of the Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers, not seasonally adjusted, for each 12-month period ending in November, with rounding to the nearest million dollars (see comment 35(b)(2)(iii)-1.iii for the current threshold); and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D
paragraph.content: Neither the creditor nor its affiliate maintains an escrow account of the type described in paragraph (b)(1) of this section for any extension of consumer credit secured by real property or a dwelling that the creditor or its affiliate currently services, other than:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D-1
paragraph.content: Escrow accounts established for first-lien higher-priced mortgage loans on or after April 1, 2010, and before June 1, 2013; or

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D-2
paragraph.content: Escrow accounts established after consummation as an accommodation to distressed consumers to assist such consumers in avoiding default or foreclosure.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iv
paragraph.content: For purposes of paragraph (b)(2)(iii)(A) of this section:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iv-A
paragraph.content: A county is “rural” during a calendar year if it is neither in a metropolitan statistical area nor in a micropolitan statistical area that is adjacent to a metropolitan statistical area, as those terms are defined by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget and as they are applied under currently applicable Urban Influence Codes (UICs), established by the United States Department of Agriculture's Economic Research Service (USDA-ERS). A creditor may rely as a safe harbor on the list of counties published by the Bureau to determine whether a county qualifies as “rural” for a particular calendar year.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iv-B
paragraph.content: A county is “underserved” during a calendar year if, according to Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA) data for the preceding calendar year, no more than two creditors extended covered transactions, as defined in § 1026.43(b)(1), secured by a first lien, five or more times in the county. A creditor may rely as a safe harbor on the list of counties published by the Bureau to determine whether a county qualifies as “underserved” for a particular calendar year.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-v
paragraph.content: Notwithstanding paragraph (b)(2)(iii) of this section, an escrow account must be established pursuant to paragraph (b)(1) of this section for any first-lien higher-priced mortgage loan that, at consummation, is subject to a commitment to be acquired by a person that does not satisfy the conditions in paragraph (b)(2)(iii) of this section, unless otherwise exempted by this paragraph (b)(2).

paragraph.label: 1026-35-a-2
paragraph.content: “Average prime offer rate” means an annual percentage rate that is derived from average interest rates, points, and other loan pricing terms currently offered to consumers by a representative sample of creditors for mortgage transactions that have low-risk pricing characteristics. The Bureau publishes average prime offer rates for a broad range of types of transactions in a table updated at least weekly as well as the methodology the Bureau uses to derive these rates.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-3-ii
paragraph.content: The dollar amounts, including the loan amounts, in paragraph (e)(3)(i) of this section shall be adjusted annually on January 1 by the annual percentage change in the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers (CPI-U) that was reported on the preceding June 1. See the official commentary to this paragraph (e)(3)(ii) for the current dollar amounts.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-a-1
paragraph.content: “Higher-priced mortgage loan” means a closed-end consumer creditit transaction secured by the consumer's principal dwelling with an annual percentage rate that exceeds the average prime offer rate for a comparable transaction as of the date the interest rate is set:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-a-1-i
paragraph.content: By 1.5 or more percentage points for loans secured by a first lien with a principal obligation at consummation that does not exceed the limit in effect as of the date the transaction's interest rate is set for the maximum principal obligation eligible for purchase by Freddie Mac;

paragraph.label: 1026-35-a-1-ii
paragraph.content: By 2.5 or more percentage points for loans secured by a first lien with a principal obligation at consummation that exceeds the limit in effect as of the date the transaction's interest rate is set for the maximum principal obligation eligible for purchase by Freddie Mac; or

paragraph.label: 1026-35-a-1-iii
paragraph.content: By 3.5 or more percentage points for loans secured by a subordinate lien.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-B
paragraph.content: Periodic payments of principal and interest that will repay either:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-B-1
paragraph.content: The outstanding principal balance over the remaining term of the loan as of the date the interest rate adjusts to the maximum interest rate set forth in paragraph (e)(2)(iv)(A) of this section, assuming the consumer will have made all required payments as due prior to that date; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-B-2
paragraph.content: The loan amount over the loan term;
